awd_titl_txt: Inductive learning of nonlocal phonological interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Language is a fundamental and universal aspect of human cognition. Linguistic research over the past five decades has established that language structure is governed by detailed rules. These rules constrain meanings, sentences, words, and sound patterns--the focus of the proposed research. For many years, sound structure was investigated primarily by theorizing. More recently, linguists have begun to test these theories using experiments and computational models. Computational models are valuable because they can only be created based on a complete and explicit understanding of the underlying rules. If the model succeeds in learning human-like rules when given the same data that is available to human learners, then it can shed some light on the rules that constitute the human knowledge of language and how humans learn these rules. In addition to helping scientists understand the human mind, computational models and the datasets they use are invaluable in developing applied computational tools for machine language translation, language identification, and artificial intelligence.

The rules that govern sound patterns differ in nuanced ways between languages, and they can be divided into two kinds. First, all languages have rules that restrict how sounds interact with sounds that immediately precede or follow them: for example, in English, words can begin in "pr" but not "pn", whereas in Greek, words can begin in either sequence. But some languages also have rules that restrict the interactions of sounds that are not adjacent (nonlocal). Languages such as Hungarian and Turkish have vowel harmony, which means that all the vowels in a word tend to share certain features of their pronunciation. Navajo (Southwestern United States) has consonant harmony--consonants have to match in certain features. In languages such as Quechua (spoken in South America) and Amharic (Africa), certain features of consonants have to mismatch. Linguists have known about these patterns for a long time, and there are many theories of how they are cognitively represented. But these nonlocal rules continue to stymie computational models, because in order to notice them, the computer has to consider many more possibilities than it would for rules on adjacent sounds. This is similar to how much more difficult it is for a computer to crack a password the longer it gets. The proposed research builds a computational model of nonlocal rules that identifies certain clues to their existence in a language. The project will compile corpora to test the model's ability to find nonlocal rules (Quechua, Shona, Hungarian, Russian, Aymara, Sundanese). The model's performance will be compared with experiments with native speakers of several languages. The model, the corpora, and the experimental data will be made freely available to the scientific community and the public. Workshops will disseminate the research in Bolivia. The project will provide training for students in computational analysis and corpus building.

por.por_cntn:
All spoken languages make use of a distinctive set of sounds and combinations of sounds. For example, English has the sounds p and b, while Bolivian Quechua has the sounds p p' and ph. A word with the sound p' will not sound like an English word to an English speaker, since English does not use this sound. Similarly, words in English may begin with the sound combination bl (as in blue) but not the sound combination bm, and so a hypothetical word like bmue would sound weird and be hard to pronounce for an English speaker.

This grant focused on languages where certain pairs of sounds do not combine within a word. For example, in Bolivian Quechua, no word contains two p' (p'acha 'clothes', jap'iy 'to have' but no words like p'ap'a), and in Shona (a language from the Bantu family spoken in Zimbabwe), no verb stems contain e followed by i (-perera 'end in' -ipira 'be evil for' but not -perira). The grant project resulted in published papers reporting on three types of research.

1. A computational learning model was developed that aims to explore how a real human learner might come to (unconsciously) know the types of sound combinations that do and do not exist in their language. The model is a computer program that takes as input a list of words in a language, and gives as output a prediction for whether a particular combination of sounds is allowable or not. For example, the model successfully predicts that a word with two p' sounds in Bolivian Quechua is not possible, based on evaluating the list of words that do exist. The computational model was tested on several languages: Bolivian Quechua, Bolivian Aymara, Shona, Totonac, Navajo, and Nkore-Kiga. The project also developed a computational model for analyzing ambiguous sequences that pattern as two sounds in some languages ("ts" in English) but as one in other languages ("ts" in German). This model is available as a website, along with corpora of 24 languages from every continent.

2. Corpus studies were conducted on the above languages, detailing the statistical patterns in the words of each language. Particular attention was paid to the difference between words (which may be complex and contain a root and one or more affixes, as in un-believ-able) and roots (which contain just one meaningful element, as in believe).

3. In a behavioral experiment, speakers of Bolivian Aymara were asked to repeat nonsense words. Bolivian Aymara speakers made errors in repetition on words with two 'ejective' sounds like k'ast'a (saying k?asta instead with a t instead of a t?), where the ejective k? and ejective t? were interpreted as being part of a single root word. When the same sequence of sounds was presented as part of a verb k?as-t?a-?a, but not part of a single root, speakers did not make errors. In Bolivian Aymara, t?a and ?a are both suffixes that appear on verb roots.

Intellectual merit This project contributes to our understanding of human language by proposing models of learning that are successful at learning sound combinations, an aspect of language that is not handled well in existing models. The learning models are available for use by other researchers, with documentation on how to construct the input training data, and the evaluation of its output is discussed in detail in published papers. A second lacuna in the existing literature that this project fills is to test the models in a detailed way on large data sets from a variety of languages. Much computational work uses highly simplified data sets or summarizes over results in a way that obscures linguistically meaningful details (like patterns of sounds in roots as opposed to complex words).

Broader impacts The project provided training opportunities for three Bolivian linguists who are native speakers of Quechua. The results of portions of the research were presented to Bolivian audiences which included academic and non-academic individuals, hopefully enriching the understanding of language structure of people interested in language-related fields in Bolivia. Finally, the grant provided funds for a training workshop for speakers of Bolivian Amazonian languages.
